headline.main: A Bubble Watcher Watches Google

docs.snippet: A CHALLENGE TO PAY-PER-CLICK -- Shopping.com, Shopzilla.com and PriceGrabber.com made attractive acquisitions last year, partly because all were following Google's pay-per-click advertising model. The sites offer search boxes and product directori...
docs.lead_paragraph: A CHALLENGE TO PAY-PER-CLICK -- Shopping.com, Shopzilla.com and PriceGrabber.com made attractive acquisitions last year, partly because all were following Google's pay-per-click advertising model. The sites offer search boxes and product directories, typically presenting items so that when users click on a link, they are in essence clicking on a merchant's ad. But new sites, like Jellyfish, TheFind and MyTriggers, are taking advantage of an increasing discomfort with the pay-per-click model. On these new sites, advertisers typically pay only when someone buys something or when users view an ad. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C6.] AN OUTLET FOR PHOTOS -- Hoping to turn the millions of people with digital cameras and camera phones into photojournalists, Yahoo and Reuters are introducing an effort to showcase photographs and video of news events submitted by the public. Starting tomorrow, the photos and videos submitted will be placed throughout Reuters.com and Yahoo News. Reuters said that it would start to distribute some submissions to media outlets that subscribe to its news service. [C6.] ARTICLE BLOCKED IN RUSSIA -- In a sign of the growing reach of Russia's business elite, a billionaire, Yelena Baturina, tried -- and for a time succeeded -- in blocking an article in the Russian edition of Forbes magazine that featured her on its cover. The episode again raised questions about intimidation of the press. The December edition appeared on newsstands a day late and after the editor in chief, Maksim Kashulinsky, above, resigned in protest. [C4.] ASK GOES LOCAL -- Like every other major search company, Ask would like to narrow Google's lead, and it has made some progress. In the last four months, Ask has regained market share that it lost last year. And on Monday, Ask.com is introducing AskCity, a service that integrates maps with information about local businesses, restaurants, concerts and movies. [C1.] IN BRITAIN, THE ONLINE FUTURE -- Online advertising in Britain offers a glimpse of the future for the ad world, growing at a roughly 40 percent annual rate. It is expected to account for as much as 14 percent of overall ad spending this year in Britain, the highest level in the world, and more than double the percentage in America. Advertising. [C1.] WAL-MART TRIES TO RAISE MORALE -- Faced with demonstrations of discontent by its employees, Wal-Mart Stores has developed a program to show that it appreciates its 1.3 million workers in the United States and to encourage them to air their grievances. As part of the effort, Wal-Mart managers will hold monthly meetings with rank-and-file workers and extend a 10 percent discount on a single product during the holidays to all its employees. [C1.] WA LL STREET JOURNAL REDESIGN -- Executives of The Wall Street Journal will unveil today the prototype for its redesign, part of a $100 million overhaul beginning on Jan. 2 that will shrink the physical size of the paper. This will save money but also reduce the space devoted to news by 10 percent. Many of the changes are intended to help the time-pressed reader move through the paper faster. [C4.] PRIME-TIME CHANGES AT CNN -- While the daytime ratings at Headline News have grown a modest 10 percent among viewers coveted by advertisers, those from ages 25 to 54, the ratings are up 48 percent at Headline Prime, the prime-time program that summarizes the news, into brash, personality-driven talk-TV. But with the improved ratings come a question: how can CNN compete with the more opinionated prime-time competition while preserving its reputation as an objective news gatherer? [C1.] FOCUS ON TELECOM GROUP -- This week, the International Telecommunication Union, a United Nations agency representing 191 countries and 650 companies, puts on the telecommunications industry's biggest gathering, called ITU Telecom World. But some of the conference's attention will be focused on the role of the ITU itself. Should it concern itself with Internet governance, or should it focus on more basic issues, like access to telecommunications in developing countries? [C12.] CITGO PAYS FOR ADS -- Citizens Energy Corporation, the nonprofit heating assistance program, supplies low-income households with oil provided by Citgo, the state-owned Venezuelan oil company. Now for the first time Citgo is also funding Citizens' television commercials, left. The commercials, which advertise ''heating oil at 40 percent off from our friends in Venezuela at Citgo,'' began airing on Nov. 17 in local television markets for the 16 states reached by Citizens Energy. Citgo supplied Citizens with oil last year, but this year is the first time that Citgo will be paying for the Citizens commercials. [C8.] A SALE, BUT NOT A TITLE -- When HarperCollins announced the impending release of ''If I Did It,'' O. J. Simpson's book about his ex-wife's murder, the title, author and subject came as a surprise to almost everyone -- including the booksellers who had already ordered the book. Mr. Simpson's book, which was canceled, was sold ''blind'' to bookstores a few weeks before its release, a phenomena that is increasingly common in the publishing industry. [C8.] VIDEO GAMES ON TV -- Competitive video gaming is going to get shot at mainstream network treatment when an hourlong special about the World Series of Video Games appears as part of the CBS Sports Spectacular lineup on Dec. 30. [C8.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Stock sales by America's corporate chieftains exceeded purchases last month by the widest margin since 1987, a sign they don't share the confidence of investors who sent the Standard & Poor's 500 Index to a six-year high. Executives including Microsoft's Bill Gates, Google's Eric Schmidt and Kohl's William Kellogg in aggregate sold $63.18 of shares for every $1 they bought in November, an analysis by Bloomberg of data from the Washington Service showed. Advances by Microsoft, Google and Kohl's have helped push the S&P 500 up 13 percent this year.

docs.snippet: This year, the philanthropic community witnessed the opening moves of Google.org, a for-profit entity through which Google plans to conduct its charitable operations. As a profit-making enterprise, Google.org can do certain things that by law a no...
docs.lead_paragraph: This year, the philanthropic community witnessed the opening moves of Google.org, a for-profit entity through which Google plans to conduct its charitable operations. As a profit-making enterprise, Google.org can do certain things that by law a nonprofit cannot. It can decide for itself what counts as a worthy cause, rather than hewing to the Internal Revenue Service’s definition of a tax-exempt charity. And if Google.org succeeds at financing, say, the invention of the next generation of hybrid cars, it can make money even as it makes the planet a better place.

headline.main: For-Profit Philanthropy

docs.snippet: Karl Marx famously predicted that industrial capitalism’s individualist ethos would engender its opposite: a new collective consciousness that would ultimately fuel the socialist revolution. But the old dialectician would probably have been shoc...
docs.lead_paragraph: Karl Marx famously predicted that industrial capitalism’s individualist ethos would engender its opposite: a new collective consciousness that would ultimately fuel the socialist revolution. But the old dialectician would probably have been shocked to see how much collectivism has flowered in the hypercapitalist Internet economy of late. First there was open-source software — large-scale digital engineering projects miraculously executed by groups of programmers contributing their intellectual labor for the sheer reward of participation. Then Google took on the seemingly insurmountable problem of organizing the Web’s information by tapping the collective wisdom embedded in the links between Web sites. Then Wikipedia applied the open-source model to encyclopedia production, and — against all odds — built a genuine challenger to Britannica in four short years.

docs.snippet: TechCrunch, the blog that first broke the news that Google would acquire YouTube, is fueling speculation about the potential sale of another video-sharing site. The blog was following up on rumors that surfaced late last week, when Israeli news si...
docs.lead_paragraph: TechCrunch, the blog that first broke the news that Google would acquire YouTube, is fueling speculation about the potential sale of another video-sharing site. The blog was following up on rumors that surfaced late last week, when Israeli news site Globes Online indicated that Metacafe, an Israel-based company with an office in Palo Alto, Calif., is "close to being acquired by a foreign company for as much as $300 million." Asked about the report by Reuters, Metacafe declined to comment.

docs.snippet: A recent string of successful high-tech public offerings is lifting spirits in the nation's venture-capital community and giving hope to managers of troubled bubble-era funds. Venture investors in Silicon Valley and on the East Coast say their out...
docs.lead_paragraph: A recent string of successful high-tech public offerings is lifting spirits in the nation's venture-capital community and giving hope to managers of troubled bubble-era funds. Venture investors in Silicon Valley and on the East Coast say their outlook is suddenly less gloomy and their forecasts more bullish for a rebound in returns for this still recuperating industry. V.C.'s frequently single out Acme Packet, Riverbed Technology and Commvault Systems as examples of successful I.P.O.'s. While none mirror Google's rocket-ship I.P.O. in 2004, they proved solid deals that held their value.

docs.snippet: The plan for Facebook is "definitely not" to sell it, Facebook board member Peter Thiel told Bloomberg News in an article published online Friday. "The plan is to actually build it, maybe at some point take it public," he said. Facebook, the socia...
docs.lead_paragraph: The plan for Facebook is "definitely not" to sell it, Facebook board member Peter Thiel told Bloomberg News in an article published online Friday. "The plan is to actually build it, maybe at some point take it public," he said. Facebook, the social-networking site that began as an online hangout for students, has inspired rampant takeover speculation, especially since Google snapped up video-sharing start-up YouTube for $1.65 billion in stock. Last month, Facebook's founder, Mark Zuckerberg, was the "it" boy at the FourSquare media and technology conference, where he was approached by throngs of high-powered would-be suitors.

headline.main: Facebook's Not for Sale, Director Says

docs.snippet: When YouTube emerged as one of the Internet's most popular Web sites last year, many TV executives dismissed it as a flash in the pan – and a largely illegal one at that. But after Google agreed to pay $1.65 billion for YouTube in October, they ...
docs.lead_paragraph: When YouTube emerged as one of the Internet's most popular Web sites last year, many TV executives dismissed it as a flash in the pan - and a largely illegal one at that. But after Google agreed to pay $1.65 billion for YouTube in October, they adopted a radically different stance: suddenly they wanted to take it on. Now, a handful of giant media companies, like NBC Universal, the News Corporation, Viacom and possibly CBS, are close to announcing a new Web site that will feature some of their best-known television programming and other clips in an attempt to build a business for distributing video on the Internet to rival YouTube. The new business could be announced as soon as this week.

docs.snippet: $9 BILLION DEAL FOR REALOGY Realogy, the real estate franchisor that owns Coldwell Banker, Century 21 and Sotheby's International Realty, agreed to be sold to the Apollo Group, the private equity firm, for about $9 billion. [C1.]    SOME FLATTERY ...
docs.lead_paragraph: $9 BILLION DEAL FOR REALOGY Realogy, the real estate franchisor that owns Coldwell Banker, Century 21 and Sotheby's International Realty, agreed to be sold to the Apollo Group, the private equity firm, for about $9 billion. [C1.] SOME FLATTERY FOR YOUTUBE When YouTube emerged as one of the Internet's most popular Web sites last year, many TV executives dismissed it as a flash in the pan -- and a largely illegal one at that. But after Google agreed to pay $1.65 billion for YouTube in October, they adopted a radically different stance. Now a handful of giant media companies are close to announcing a new Web site that will feature some of their best-known television programming in an attempt to build a business for distributing video on the Internet to rival YouTube. [C1.] GOING WHERE THE EYES ARE When Det. Sgt. Jorge Lasso of Hamilton, Ontario, wanted to circulate a surveillance video while investigating an apparent murder near a hip-hop club, he posted it on YouTube. [C5] HARD TIMES FOR LIBERAL RADIO Air America, the liberal radio network that was started with an onslaught of publicity in spring 2004 as an alternative to conservative talk radio, faces the probable departure of its most visible host, Al Franken, even as it cobbles together its plan to emerge from Chapter 11. [C1.] BUSINESS DECISION On SIMPSON When News Corporation killed Judith Regan's multimedia introduction of her O. J. Simpson ''hypothetical confession,'' Rupert Murdoch called the project ''ill conceived.'' The phrase he should have used was ''ill received.'' The book and television package wasn't shelved because it was in bad taste, but because it was bad for business. The Media Equation: David Carr. [C1.] A MIRACLE OF THE MUSIC INDUSTRY The past several winters have been mean seasons for the music industry, filled with talk of declining CD sales, rumors of layoffs and uncertainty about the digital future. But a band called Trans-Siberian Orchestra has sold more than half a million Christmas albums and packed arenas across America with elaborate, effects-filled concerts. [C1.] CHINA PICKS U.S. NUCLEAR PLANTs China will buy four Westinghouse nuclear reactors worth up to $8 billion in a deal that shows the continued attractiveness of American technology, but may also stir worries in Washington that the United States is selling its competitive advantage an industry at a time. [C2.] DEFENDING THE DIAMOND TRADE The dialogue surrounding the Warner Brothers film ''Blood Diamond'' and its implicit criticism of the diamond industry took a new turn this month, as the hip-hop producer and entertainment mogul Russell Simmons, above, returned from an industry-paid trip to Africa and began vocally defending the diamond trade. [C5.] WINNERS AND LOSERS IN 2006 ADS The time has come to review the best and the worst of Madison Avenue's offerings in 2006. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C8.] SPEEDING UP HOLIDAY DELIVERIES Forces of the corporate world are set to bail out holiday shopping slackers yet again, but you would not know how unless you somehow noticed that delivery trucks are making fewer left-hand turns than ever. E-Commerce Report. [C6.] GOOGLE'S STRUGGLES IN RUSSIA Sergey Brin, left, one of the founders of Google, was born in Moscow in 1973, and the first words out of his mouth were Russian. Yet Google is behind the curve in Russia, trailing local Internet companies in executing searches and collecting rubles on the ads linked to those searches. [C11.] QUICK-CHANGE BILLBOARDS An Israeli company has developed a billboard that uses a type of synthetically produced cholesterol to help display full-color digital images that can easily be changed. [C7.] OPPOSITION TO A TRADEMARK Because of a group of law students, the makers of a controversial new energy drink have hit a snag in their attempts to register a federal trademark on Cocaine. [C4.]

docs.snippet: MORGAN STANLEY TO SPIN OFF UNIT -- Morgan Stanley said it would spin off its slow-growing credit card unit, Discover, in a tacit recognition that its success lies with the traditional heart of the firm, its lucrative trading and investment banking...
docs.lead_paragraph: MORGAN STANLEY TO SPIN OFF UNIT -- Morgan Stanley said it would spin off its slow-growing credit card unit, Discover, in a tacit recognition that its success lies with the traditional heart of the firm, its lucrative trading and investment banking business. [Page C1.] NASD SAYS E-MAIL WAS WITHHELD -- NASD accused Morgan Stanley of routinely failing to provide e-mail messages to aggrieved customers who had filed arbitration cases against the firm and with making false claims that millions of e-mail messages in its possession had been lost in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. [C6.] CONGRESS LAGS STATES ON WAGES -- On the verge of controlling Congress, the Democrats are making a much-delayed increase in the minimum wage their signature attempt to lift incomes and quiet widespread economic anxiety. But the party's proposal does not catch up with what the states have already done. [C1.] GOOGLE TAKES ON PAYPAL -- Google is aggressively promoting the Checkout online payment system it introduced in June, and its use with some merchants has already surpassed PayPal's. [C1.] VICTIM'S FATHER SUES SIMPSON -- Fred Goldman, the father of the murder victim Ronald L. Goldman, sued O. J. Simpson for fraud, charging that a recent book and television deal were structured to cheat Mr. Goldman out of damages owed him from a civil judgment. [E1.] GATESES AIM FOR RARE DISEASES -- The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is giving $47 million in grants for the control of neglected tropical diseases, now almost forgotten in wealthy nations, that still cause excruciating pain and disability for millions of the world's poorest people, the recipients announced. [A5.] THE MALL CAPITAL IN NEW JERSEY -- Paramus, N.J., has become one of the nation's strongest shopping magnets, with four major malls and dozens of smaller shopping centers. They generate roughly $5 billion a year in retail sales. [A1.] NEW WARNINGS OVER PAINKILLERS -- The dangers of over-the-counter painkillers like acetaminophen, ibuprofen, naproxen and ketoprofen would be prominently highlighted on the labels of hundreds of common drugstore remedies under a proposal announced by the Food and Drug Administration. [A18.] STUDY PREDICTS FORECLOSURES -- About one in five subprime mortgages made in the last two years -- about 1.1 million homeowners -- will go into foreclosure in the next few years, according to a report. [C4.] LONDON EXCHANGE SCORNS NASDAQ -- The London Stock Exchange dug in its heels, hoping to foil Nasdaq's takeover attempts, even as Euronext and the New York Stock Exchange moved closer to the first trans-Atlantic exchange deal. [C4.] DELTA REJECTS RIVAL'S BID -- In a plan to exit bankruptcy, Delta Air Lines' valued the carrier at $9.4 billion to $12 billion and said its board rejected US Airways' $8.5 billion bid. [C4.] WHOLESALE PRICES ON THE RISE -- Wholesale prices unexpectedly rose in November, a sobering reminder that inflation remains a threat to the economy despite recent signs that prices were settling down. [C12.] SOFTER TONE ON CURRENCY -- The Bush administration, softening its tone of criticism toward China, reported to Congress that the Chinese had made strides in reforming the nation's currency policies but that the progress was ''considerably less than is needed.'' [C12.] STRING OF DEALS FOR EQUITY FIRM -- In the course of just three days, Leon D. Black, left, the enigmatic founder of the private equity firm Apollo Group, has struck more than $37 billion worth of deals, capped by yesterday's $27 billion deal for Harrah's Entertainment, done in tandem with the Texas Pacific Group. [C1.] INVESTORS DOUBT ARTIFICIAL BLOOD -- Northfield Laboratories, an Illinois company that has struggled since 1985 to create a safe and effective blood substitute, claimed to have surmounted a major hurdle, but investors had their doubts, sending the shares down sharply in after-hours trading. [C12.] DOW INCHES UP -- The Dow Jones industrial average finished at a record high as a rise in oil prices bolstered shares of Exxon Mobil, outweighing investors' concerns about a jump in a critical inflation gauge. [C14.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. CIRCUIT CITY STORES reported a surprise quarterly loss after it cut prices on hot electronics like flat-panel TVs and computers to lure customers during the holiday shopping season. Its shares dropped sharply. (REUTERS) THE UNITEDHEALTH GROUP said income for 1994 through 2005 might be reduced by as much as $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion to correct improper accounting for options awarded to executives and employees. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) NOMURA HOLDINGS, Japan's biggest securities firm, will buy a 15 percent stake in the Fortress Investment Group, a United States hedge fund and private equity manager with $26 billion under management. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) SONY BMG MUSIC Entertainment will pay $1.5 million and kick in thousands more in customer refunds to settle lawsuits brought by California and Texas over music CDs that installed a hidden antipiracy program on consumers' computers. (AP)

docs.snippet: The Bagger has enough of a tether on contemporary culture to know why Paris Hilton was the top news search on Google News. But can someone explain to him why Orlando Bloom is number two? The hottie effect? A "Pirates" bounty? A burst of forgivenes...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger has enough of a tether on contemporary culture to know why Paris Hilton was the top news search on Google News. But can someone explain to him why Orlando Bloom is number two? The hottie effect? A "Pirates" bounty? A burst of forgiveness for "Elizabethtown?" Let's just say that Bloom's charisma blows a whistle that the Bagger cannot hear.

headline.main: We'll Always Have Paris, but Let's Move to Orlando

docs.abstract: The Bagger has enough of a tether on contemporary culture to know why Paris Hilton was the top news search on Google News. But can someone explain to him why Orlando Bloom is number two? The hottie effect? A "Pirates" bounty? A burst of forgiveness for "Elizabethtown?" Let's just say that Bloom's charisma blows a [...]
